However, Leicestershire's new-ball attack, spearheaded by Chris Wright, exerted relentless pressure. Glamorgan ended the day at 28 for 1, with Selman falling cheaply, caught at slip from an excellent delivery by Gavin Griffiths. Northeast (15*) and Marnus Labuschagne (8*) are set to continue tomorrow, with Glamorgan trailing by a significant 387 runs. The game remains delicately balanced; Leicestershire holds a distinct advantage thanks to Dearden's exceptional knock and Pettini's solid finish, yet Glamorgan must lean on their strong batting order to counter on what appears to be an accommodating pitch. Securing early wickets on day two will be paramount for both teams as this Championship encounter intensifies.

Sunderland has completed the permanent signing of the 27-year-old, a former England youth international who left Chelsea in 2018. His move follows a loan spell at Everton, where he sought consistent first-team football. Beginning in a youth academy, he represented England at junior levels prior to his senior international debut.

News of the event's concept first surfaced at 2 pm. After numerous unverified reports and several changes to the proposed venue, tickets for the show at Koko in Camden finally went on sale by 7 pm. Despite enduring hours in the frigid night air, fans patiently awaited Kanye's emergence on stage, which occurred around 1:20 am. His powerful allure was undeniable; the palpable excitement superseded the late hour and biting cold. The moment the stage lights dimmed and the music began, a unified roar erupted from the packed Koko, instantly making the extensive wait worthwhile. Kanye, renowned for his dynamic and frequently unpredictable live performances, then delivered an impressive set, seamlessly blending tracks from his vast discography with brand-new compositions. A strong, authentic bond formed between the artist and his devoted audience, fostering an electrifying atmosphere.

However, the night offered additional surprises for those present. Mid-performance, the entire ambiance dramatically shifted with the arrival of London's grime legends. The celebrated Skepta made an abrupt, explosive entrance, igniting the venue with an intense display that confirmed their long-rumored collaboration. The crowd was already elated when JME joined his brother on stage, further amplifying the sky-high energy with his thrilling contribution. Witnessing these icons perform together was truly extraordinary, a genuine fusion of distinct musical cultures. Adding an international dimension, Vic Mensa, a frequent collaborator with Kanye, also made an unscheduled appearance, showcasing his distinctive vocal prowess. Both long-time devotees and first-time concert attendees savored every moment of this significant, unconventional spectacle. It proved to be a chaotic yet exceptional night, cementing Kanye's reputation for pioneering and unforgettable events, and leaving an indelible mark on London's vibrant musical landscape and on the dedicated fans who braved the elements for such a unique experience.

Josh Taylor, a prominent Commonwealth gold medallist, achieved a significant milestone in his burgeoning professional career with a highly anticipated debut. This momentous occasion unfolded before an enthusiastic home crowd at a completely sold-out Meadowbank Arena. After the swift conclusion of the bout, Taylor conveyed his astonishment to BBC Scotland, remarking, "I absolutely did not anticipate it ending so rapidly." His manager, Barry McGuigan, was effusive in his commendation of Taylor, proclaiming him to be "exceptionally talented" and emphasizing the critical need for meticulous opponent selection at pivotal junctures of his professional progression.

Mate, Taylor’s Hungarian adversary, stepped into the ring boasting a commendable professional record of 17 victories from 22 contests. Nevertheless, the instant the opening bell sounded, it became unmistakably clear that Mate was confronting an incredibly formidable challenge. Taylor, whose reputation preceded him for devastating power and intelligent ring craft, wasted no time asserting his dominance. He glided gracefully around the canvas, masterfully cornering his opponent and unleashing a barrage of crisp, accurate jabs that swiftly began to leave their mark on Mate’s face. The Edinburgh spectators, already charged with an electric buzz of excitement, erupted in enthusiastic cheers with every successful strike landed. Taylor's left-handed southpaw stance and incredibly powerful left hand created profound difficulties for Mate, who appeared utterly unable to find his rhythm or connect with any effective return punches.

Barely sixty seconds into the fiercely contested bout, Taylor unleashed a blistering, perfectly timed combination—a potent left hook followed instantly by a thunderous straight right—which sent Mate reeling uncontrollably against the ropes. The reigning Commonwealth titleholder, acutely sensing that the end was rapidly approaching, escalated his relentless attack with unyielding intensity. Mate, to his credit, demonstrated commendable resilience, valiantly attempting to grapple and withstand the ferocious onslaught, but Taylor's pinpoint precision and the sheer volume of his strikes proved simply insurmountable. Just past the halfway mark of the opening round, a perfectly executed left uppercut from Taylor violently jolted Mate's head back, swiftly followed by a crushing right hook that sent the visiting boxer crashing definitively to the canvas.

The referee promptly wasted no time commencing the count as Mate bravely yet unsteadily attempted to regain his feet, his eyes visibly glazed over. Despite his valiant effort to rise by the count of nine, Mate’s legs were undeniably unsteady, compelling the referee to make the judicious decision to halt the fight, deeming him incapable of safely continuing. The official end to the contest arrived at precisely 2 minutes and 10 seconds into the inaugural round, marking a remarkably commanding and utterly decisive performance from the Prestonpans fighter. The capacity sell-out crowd at Meadowbank Arena erupted into an enormous, celebratory roar, spontaneously rising to their feet in a resounding standing ovation for their triumphant homegrown champion.

After the conclusive bout, a smiling Taylor visibly basked in the overwhelmingly enthusiastic support of the adoring crowd, expressing profound gratitude for their steadfast encouragement throughout the evening. Speaking to BBC Scotland later that night, he again reflected on his comprehensive victory, reiterating his astonishment at its remarkably rapid conclusion. "I had genuinely braced myself for what I anticipated would be a challenging fight, potentially needing a few rounds to truly find my optimal rhythm, but I landed some exceptionally solid punches early on and simply maintained the pressure. The incredible, unwavering support from the fans was truly phenomenal; it genuinely spurred me on to perform at my very best."

Barry McGuigan, Taylor’s manager and a respected former world champion himself, observed the performance with profound satisfaction. He told reporters that "Tonight, Josh unequivocally demonstrated why we foresee an exceptional future for him." McGuigan commended Taylor's "extraordinary power, speed, and ring IQ," adding that he "flawlessly managed the pressure of competing at Meadowbank in front of his hometown supporters." He characterized it as "a definitive victory that sent a powerful message to the super-lightweight division." McGuigan re-emphasized their strategic, patient approach to Taylor's career progression: "We are not rushing anything; as I've stated before, we must select the correct fights at the optimal times to ensure his steady development. Nonetheless, he continues to refine his skills and improve with every match." He confirmed a thorough review of this performance would meticulously inform Taylor's subsequent plans, asserting, "Significant challenges await Josh, and he is ready for them. This showing merely reaffirms that he is indeed a remarkably special talent, destined for the pinnacle of the sport." This victory served as another crucial landmark in Taylor's rapidly ascending professional career. It not only paved the way for more significant tests but also unequivocally validated his formidable skills on home turf against a credible adversary, despite the fight's remarkably short duration. The palpable excitement surrounding Taylor surged dramatically following this commanding performance at Meadowbank, solidifying his standing as one of Scotland's most compelling and promising boxing prospects. This dominant display further cemented his image as a future champion in the making, building upon the foundations laid by his previous successes at the Commonwealth Games.

Belgian striker Romelu Lukaku, a recent £75 million acquisition from Everton, proved decisive for Manchester United, scoring the go-ahead goal just seven minutes before halftime. This followed an early setback where United had conceded within the first 20 minutes, though Henrikh Mkhitaryan quickly leveled the score. The team's challenges extended beyond the pitch, as they also contended with an injury to Juan Mata and Antonio Valencia's sending off.

Regarding Lukaku's pivotal strike, manager Jose Mourinho conveyed that while it offered personal satisfaction for the player, its individual significance was secondary to him. He explained, "My message to him was that the team's collective triumph and securing the three points are paramount, not his individual goal tally." Mourinho recognized the goal's importance but highlighted its occurrence amidst a particularly trying match, marked by conceding an early goal, Mata's injury, and Valencia's red card. He stressed that such demanding circumstances truly test a squad's spirit and was pleased with their resolve to clinch victory, yet he emphasized the necessity of learning from the mistakes that led to these predicaments.

Mata's injury posed a serious concern for the manager. Mourinho declared him "a crucial contributor to our squad, and his creative input will be sorely missed. We await the full diagnosis, but it appeared severe." Commenting on Valencia's dismissal, he characterized it as "an avoidable act of poor discipline, which Valencia himself acknowledges." Mourinho insisted that a seasoned professional must avoid such errors, especially those that leave the team disadvantaged and result in a suspension for the subsequent game. He added that such missteps are unacceptable for a team aspiring to major honors.

Mourinho further elaborated that "Romelu fully understands my high expectations, which go beyond merely scoring and encompass his overall contribution." He clarified his anticipation for Lukaku to actively participate in link-up play, apply pressure on opposition defenders, and consistently engage in the team's attacking build-up, rather than merely waiting for opportunities to shoot. According to Mourinho, goals naturally arise from successfully executing these broader responsibilities. He believes Lukaku possesses the potential to develop into a truly all-around forward for Manchester United, and the club intends to refine every aspect of his game.

Despite overcoming several adversities, including falling behind early, the team demonstrated commendable character to secure the win. However, Mourinho cautioned, "Our overall performance was not flawless. We occasionally allowed our opponents too much space and should have been more clinical to seal the game sooner. Continuous improvement is vital." He concluded by stating, "We will gladly take the three points, meticulously analyze areas for enhancement, and immediately shift our focus to the next fixture. With a long season stretching ahead, every player must maintain concentration, uphold discipline, and consistently deliver top-tier performances, free from costly errors."

On November 22, 1940, an aircraft from the Rhodesian Squadron Royal Air Force, stationed at RAF Wittering, crashed near Holme. The pilot, Brighton resident Pilot Officer Harold Penketh, tragically perished upon impact, having consciously decided against ejecting. Following a recent geophysical survey of the crash site, substantial debris from his Spitfire has been unearthed. These salvaged parts are destined for public display, serving as a poignant tribute to the immense sacrifices made during World War Two.

Pilot Officer Penketh, merely 20 years old, was at the controls of a Supermarine Spitfire Mk IIa, a vital fighter aircraft extensively used during and after the Battle of Britain. While the precise cause of the crash remains undetermined, it is believed he deliberately steered his malfunctioning plane away from Holme village. This action, a common practice among pilots of that era, was likely intended to safeguard the ground populace. His unwavering resolve to remain with the aircraft, despite immediate peril, exemplifies the extraordinary courage demonstrated by many young service members in wartime. Harold Penketh's ultimate sacrifice is permanently commemorated on the Brighton & Hove War Memorial.

After a successful geophysical examination identified buried metallic anomalies, an archaeological team, collaborating with aviation historians and military experts, commenced a thorough excavation. This advanced method precisely guided them to the exact crash location. Over several weeks, numerous artifacts were carefully uncovered, including engine components, fuselage fragments, cockpit instruments, and personal effects thought to belong to Pilot Officer Penketh. Each recovered piece contributes to recounting the incident, vividly illustrating the intensity of aerial combat and the severe hardships faced by those defending the nation's airspace.

Current efforts are concentrated on the conservation and stabilization of these invaluable artifacts. Plans are in motion for an exhibition, potentially situated in a local museum or a dedicated aviation heritage center. This forthcoming display will not only present the recovered Spitfire parts but also chronicle Harold Penketh's personal narrative, contextualizing it within the broader scope of the Rhodesian Squadron RAF's wartime operations from RAF Wittering. Conceived as an educational resource, the exhibition aims to permanently embed the bravery of pilots like Penketh and the Spitfire's critical role in Britain's defense into public consciousness. Its objective is to offer visitors a tangible connection to this historical event, fostering an appreciation for the profound human cost of freedom and the enduring legacy of young airmen who served from bases such as RAF Wittering. The Brighton community has shown considerable enthusiasm for honoring one of their own through this crucial historical recovery and act of remembrance. The paramount goal is to establish a fitting and lasting tribute to Pilot Officer Harold Penketh and all military personnel.

Kathryn Trussler's sculptures are fashioned from consumer waste including artificial turf and polystyrene.
Her exhibition, at Elysium Gallery from 19 May, was sparked by some unusual finds on Swansea's beach.
Ms Trussler said her work intended to make people question using non-biodegradable substances for fleeting purposes like packaging.
"The inspiration came from what I thought were just a simple pile of pebbles," she added.
"But when I looked closer I realised they were made of old, weathered expanding foam and, descending in size, they stacked on top of each other like the mass produced 'Zen stones' canvases you find at the doctor's or at a motel."

Rehtaeh Parsons, 17, of Nova Scotia, killed herself in April after being taunted over a photo of her alleged rape by four boys, her mother has said.
Two 18-year-old men were arrested on Thursday in connection with the photograph.
The men, who have not been named, will be prosecuted in a juvenile court.
"We hope that today's arrests help the community to heal," Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) Chief Superintendent Roland Wells of the Halifax district said in a statement on Thursday evening.
"A young girl has died in what was a tragic set of circumstances. We all need to reflect on how we as a community can come together in Rehtaeh's memory and see what we can do to work together to support our youth."
One of the men was charged with two counts of distribution of child pornography, the other with one count each of making child pornography and distribution of child pornography.
The RCMP said the names of the accused would not be released because they were youths at the time of the alleged offence, and warned Halifax residents who believe they know the identities of the accused not to release them on penalty of prosecution, nor to take vigilante action.
According to Rehtaeh's mother Leah Parsons, the Nova Scotia teen went to a party in 2011, when she was 15, and became inebriated after drinking vodka.
The girl told her parents that while she was heavily intoxicated, she was raped by four boys, and someone took a photograph of it.
The photograph was circulated online, and soon her schoolmates began taunting her over the photograph. The bullying was incessant, her mother said.
"She was never left alone," Ms Parsons told CBC News in April after Rehtaeh's suicide.
"Her friends turned against her, people harassed her, boys she didn't know started texting her and Facebooking asking her to have sex with them since she had had sex with their friends. It just never stopped."
Rehtaeh died in April in hospital, several days after attempting suicide.
Police at first said they did not have grounds to make any arrests in connection with the alleged rape or the photograph. The investigation was reopened in April after police said they received new information.

Rhys Webb is poised for his return to the Welsh squad, having been listed among the replacements for his first game since sustaining a foot injury in September. According to Davies, his comeback was widely anticipated, with the team expecting him back once fully recovered. Davies highlighted the significant benefit of his presence, noting Webb's extensive background, strong leadership qualities, and exceptional strategic acumen. He remarked on the immediate burst of energy Webb brings to training, which speaks volumes about his dedication during rehabilitation. This return is seen as perfectly timed, especially with crucial matches on the horizon, like the demanding Six Nations tournament, where his participation is predicted to energize the entire team.

Despite fierce competition for the scrum-half spot in Wales, Webb's proven ability distinguishes him. His unparalleled talent for dictating game pace and exploiting defensive weaknesses sets him apart, and he is eager to make an immediate impact. The foot injury from September proved more severe than initially thought, necessitating an intensive rehabilitation program. Webb displayed remarkable endurance throughout a challenging recovery period. This period away from active play has only intensified his resolve to excel for Wales. He maintained his focus despite media speculation surrounding his return, ensuring he was completely fit before stepping back onto the pitch.

The squad's attention has now turned to upcoming fixtures, particularly the much-anticipated clash against England. Webb's veteran insight is considered indispensable for these pivotal contests; his tactical understanding and composure under pressure will be crucial when confronting England's formidable play. His return also fosters healthy competition and provides mentorship to aspiring scrum-halves, thereby strengthening Wales's options in that position. The coaching staff deeply values his experienced contributions. Off the field, Webb's exemplary professionalism and leadership serve as a vital influence for a determined team aiming to build momentum for future competitions.

Davies elaborated that all players recognize the necessity of performing well to secure their place, and Webb's involvement notably elevates this standard, driving overall squad enhancement. He stressed the importance of cultivating a resilient team, effectively integrating seasoned experience with promising emerging talent to achieve sustained success. This robust competition for positions, he pointed out, motivates every individual to perform at their best. Ultimately, everyone is committed to delivering strong performances for Wales, and Webb's inclusion unequivocally bolsters their standing against any opposition, including England.

PwC's latest annual survey reveals a significant drop in economic optimism, with just 37% of business leaders anticipating an economic improvement in 2015, a decrease from 44% the previous year. Notably, Russian executives, once the most optimistic, now exhibit the lowest confidence, grappling with challenges from international sanctions and plummeting oil prices. Concurrently, concerns over the availability of skilled workers have escalated sharply in the United Kingdom. PwC identifies this shortage of crucial expertise as a significant hindrance to the UK's economic growth and its competitive position. Many British companies are finding it difficult to recruit and retain staff with essential digital and technical competencies, leading to higher expenditures on upskilling current employees and, where feasible, recruiting talent from abroad.

In contrast to the UK's talent shortage, business leaders in Germany and France highlighted distinct primary concerns. German chief executives, while marginally more positive than their French counterparts, were predominantly troubled by a reduction in global demand and geopolitical instability impacting their export-dependent sectors. The eurozone's sluggish recovery, coupled with ongoing anxieties about deflation and consumer spending, further fueled their unease. Conversely, French company heads primarily focused on domestic regulatory complexities and the pressing necessity for fundamental structural reforms to revitalize their economy. Confidence remained subdued across both countries, reflecting a cautious European outlook amidst persistent economic uncertainties and the lingering effects of the debt crisis.

On a global scale, PwC's study, which surveyed over 1,300 senior executives, underscored a widespread shift towards cautious strategies. Beyond Russia's specific challenges from sanctions and plummeting oil values, and the UK's distinct skilled labor issues, the prevailing sentiment indicated a strategic emphasis on consolidating existing operations. Globally, only 37% of chief executives anticipated economic betterment, a noticeable decline from 44%. This substantial drop signals a pervasive sense of unpredictability across diverse regions, influenced by factors ranging from fluctuating commodity prices to geopolitical tensions. CEOs reported an intensified commitment to optimizing processes, controlling costs, and pursuing measured, organic expansion, rather than aggressive growth initiatives. Investing in innovation, particularly digital technologies, emerged as a vital imperative for building resilience and maintaining a competitive advantage in an volatile international market.

On June 15, 2012, a lethal clash erupted at the Campos Morumbi estate in Curuguaty, Paraguay, during an attempt to evict farmers occupying disputed territory. This incident, commonly known as the Curuguaty Massacre, led to the deaths of six police officers and eleven protestors. The landless farmers asserted the land belonged to the state and was designated for agrarian reform. While four individuals initially received severe prison terms, ranging from 18 to 30 years, the subsequent judicial proceedings faced widespread condemnation. Human rights organizations and international observers pointed out significant due process violations and insufficient evidence to link the accused farmers to the police fatalities during the trials of the eleven individuals.

The massacre quickly ignited political unrest across Paraguay and served as the direct justification for the rapid impeachment of then-President Fernando Lugo, a left-leaning leader, by the national congress. His removal, occurring merely days after the killings, was largely seen as a politically motivated maneuver to undermine his initiatives for land reform. Consequently, regional alliances like MERCOSUR and UNASUR denounced Lugo's dismissal as an 'institutional coup,' leading to Paraguay's temporary suspension from these organizations.

Despite convictions being issued in 2016, a pivotal moment arrived in July 2017 when Paraguay's Supreme Court of Justice invalidated the sentences against all eleven farmers, including those previously mentioned. Citing a lack of robust evidence and significant procedural flaws, this momentous decision resulted in their immediate freedom. The Curuguaty affair thus represents an intricate legal journey, highlighting Paraguay's deep-seated land conflicts and political divisions, and remains a potent symbol in the nation's ongoing pursuit of equitable land access.

The 23-year-old left the field during the first half of the Dragons' defeat by Ospreys on New Year's Day.
"Dorian has had a pectoral injury, which looks quite serious," said Dragons director of rugby Lyn Jones.
"It could be a few months, which is a blow to us because he's right on top of his game, starting to challenge for national honours behind Dan Biggar."
Scrum-half Sarel Pretorius was also forced off at the Liberty Stadium with a recurrence of a calf injury.
But the Dragons will welcome back Hallam Amos and Tyler Morgan later this month.
The Wales internationals have not played since suffering shoulder injuries during the World Cup but at least one could be fit in time for the crucial European Challenge Cup ties at home to Castres on 15 January.
Media playback is not supported on this device
"They are big-time players who can offer something different," added Dragons boss Jones.
"There's a good chance one of them will be back [to face Castres], which one I'm not sure.
"They've made really good progress and the medical department need to be congratulated for getting them back with such speed.
"They've recovered very well and we expected both of them to be playing some part in the European competition shortly."

The Official Charts Company has verified an unparalleled historic achievement: a single artist has simultaneously secured the top two positions on the music charts with two brand-new songs. The renowned vocalist communicated his profound joy, stating he was "incredibly chuffed" by this accomplishment. He further noted, "Both tracks mean a huge amount to me, so it really is amazing to see them go to the top of the chart together." This victorious re-emergence follows Sheeran's year-long hiatus, during which he deliberately disengaged from social media and touring to explore the globe and "see more than the inside of a studio or a hotel room." This temporary retreat from public scrutiny evidently proved beneficial, allowing him to reconnect with his foundations and discover fresh inspiration, powerfully demonstrated by his unmatched chart dominance. The Official Charts Company further affirmed this dual chart-topping debut as a truly significant event, emphasizing the immense public eagerness for new material from the internationally beloved singer-songwriter.

These two singles, 'Shape of You' and 'Castle on the Hill,' brilliantly showcase the spectrum of Sheeran's musical talents. 'Shape of You' is a captivating, rhythm-driven pop track featuring subtle dance influences, whereas 'Castle on the Hill' serves as a moving, anthemic tribute to his upbringing in Framlingham, Suffolk, capturing the essence of rural life and youthful connections. This distinct contrast in styles underscores his adaptability and widespread appeal, garnering him both critical recognition and vast commercial triumph. The immediate success of both compositions further confirms the efficacy of his carefully planned return to the music scene.

This extraordinary feat transpired within a fiercely competitive musical environment. While other artists, such as Drake, have recently maintained strong chart presence with multiple popular songs, Sheeran's simultaneous occupation of the top two spots marks an unparalleled benchmark, highlighting his unique talent and dedicated fanbase. His comeback has undeniably invigorated the UK charts, generating renewed excitement and establishing an unprecedented standard for chart performance.

In response to the news, Sheeran once more expressed deep gratitude to his supporters, acknowledging the considerable effort and personal significance invested in both creations. "It's been a long time coming," he commented, hinting at the diligent songwriting and production undertaken during his period away. He added, "To have both songs resonate so deeply with people, especially 'Castle on the Hill' which is so personal, means the world to me." The Official Charts Company also pointed out the remarkable volume of streams and downloads for the two tracks, far exceeding all rivals. This unparalleled success firmly establishes Sheeran's standing as a leading and highly esteemed artist of his generation, proving that a pause can sometimes foster even greater achievements. His unique capacity to connect personally with listeners, paired with his undeniable songwriting skill, continues to distinguish him in the global music arena. Fans eagerly anticipate more details about his upcoming album, now expected to be one of the year's most important releases. The strong initial reception to these singles suggests his "gap year" only enhanced his creative output, leading to an even more refined and impactful sound. The international music community closely observes as Sheeran persists in innovating and reshaping chart trends, displaying lasting appeal across diverse genres and demographics.

Chris Millar is also out while Keith Watson and Ally Gilchrist are not quite ready to return.
Ross County defender Paul Quinn will be given a week off after playing against Rangers with a knock.
Michael Gardyne and Martin Woods return after missing the draw with the Ibrox side while Erik Cikos has recovered from a dead leg.
St Johnstone's Ricky Foster: "It was good getting a win up there earlier in the season and I'm hoping for more of the same.
"You always want to do well against an old team. You have a point to prove and want to come out on top.
"These are good games to play in, as long as you win."
Ross County's Alex Schalk: "We have a massive opportunity on Saturday to narrow the gap with St Johnstone as well but you can't keep saying that.
"You have to grab these opportunities. We are going to go on a run now that will help us back into the top six, I am confident of that.
"The manager wants us to be an established top-six side, that has worked well so far but we have had a bad start.
"We can look up to St Johnstone and how well they are doing but I think with the ability we have in this group, we should be there as well."

From Winston Churchill's infamous visit to Belfast in 1912 to a 1963 Viking invasion re-enactment in a County Down fishing town, as well as tales of tourism, industrial heritage and sport, a dazzling mosaic of Ulster life is pieced together in unseen archive footage.
Hundreds of unique films have been released to the public to view online for free after the British Film Institute (BFI) unlocked its archive as part of a major history project, From Britain On Film.
Royal visits and Lord Mayor's shows are documented in the collection, as is the tale of Churchill's appearance in Belfast when he addressed an audience of nationalists in Celtic Park and gave his support to Home Rule.
There are also dozens of travelogues that were used to sell Northern Ireland to tourists in Great Britain and the United States, helping to boost tourism in the years before the Troubles.
And in sport, the 1930 Ulster Tourist Trophy race held at the Ards circuit in County Down is captured on camera. The event attracted thousands of spectators and commanded the attention of the motorsport world.
The real gems, however, are found in the footage of ordinary people doing extraordinary things.
Films of people at work in the spinning mills and constructing the M1 at Stockman's Lane in Belfast shows Northern Ireland's industry at its booming best.
Another film captures the first time Northern Ireland hosted the World Ploughing Championships, and fittingly it is a local man who takes the title.
The colour footage from the 1959 competition in Armoy, County Antrim, shows Lawrence McMillan's crowning moment as he gets his hands on the Golden Plough.
But perhaps most revealing of all is a 1938 recording of the Royal Victoria Hospital in Belfast.
It gives a rare glimpse into the casualty department and operating theatres as they were then, 10 years before the foundation of the National Health Service.
While medicine has advanced considerably in the eight decades since then, some aspects of healthcare in Northern Ireland appear to remain unchanged - the film ends with an appeal from the chairman of the hospital's management board to reduce waiting lists.
Francis Jones, of Northern Ireland Screen, which gathered much of the footage, said the aim of the project was to preserve delicate film that could otherwise be lost.
"There is a pure nostalgia value to film. It's different to reading a textbook or history book," he added.
"To actually see the film has that kind of visceral appeal and really strikes a chord with people."
The full From Britain On Film archive can be viewed at the BFI Player.

North Ronaldsay Primary School's single classroom will be kept on standby from August as Teigan Scott, 12, moves to secondary in Kirkwall.
Orkney's most northerly island only has a population of about 50 people.
Orkney Islands Council said the school would be brought back into use if more families with young children moved to the island.
The building is also used by community groups.
Island residents have blamed poor transport links for the lack of young families.
Teigan told the BBC she was looking forward to moving on to secondary but worried for the future of her former school.
"I am excited to go up to the bigger school," she said.
"But I have a tiny little drop of sadness because the school will be closing and the island might fall apart."
Councillor Kevin Woodbridge said the population on North Ronaldsay had halved since he arrived in 1977.
He said: "It's very sad but it demonstrates the decline on the island that has led to this.
"When I came here there were 17 people at the school and 127 on the island, now we have 50 to 60 people.
"The quality of life on the island can be improved considerably."
Billy Muir, chairman of the community council, said the loss of the school's only pupil was "a very serious blow for the community and no doubt will have a knock-on effect".
He said: "We need new housing to be built and to get new families in. You want a number of kids in the school, not just one.
"Higher speed broadband is needed too.
"There's no point painting a good picture, we have to be realistic. Hopefully this highlights our problem."
A spokesman for the local authority said: "North Ronaldsay Primary School's single classroom is part of a building housing a range of community facilities.
"The classroom will be kept on standby from August onwards and would be used as a school room again if a family or families with primary-age children move to the island.
"In the meantime, it will remain open for people of all ages in North Ronaldsay to use for a range of learning activities, managed by the local community association.
"This approach to keeping the room actively in use has been developed in discussion between Orkney Islands Council and a number of community groups in North Ronaldsay."

Convenience store chain My Local, which had been operating 125 branches, will promptly shut down 93 of them. The other 32 sites are expected to remain open temporarily as administrators search for interested purchasers; without a successful acquisition, these locations will also inevitably close. The business had a staff of 1,658 people. Greybull Capital acquired the chain, then known as Morrisons M Local, from the supermarket major Morrisons in September 2015. This sale aligned with Morrisons' strategy to focus on larger supermarkets and move away from smaller convenience stores. Despite considerable financial support from Morrisons, including a loan of up to £25 million aimed at stabilizing and revitalizing the company, My Local faced significant difficulties after the takeover. This substantial investment ultimately proved insufficient to halt its decline within an intensely competitive market, where it competed against strong contenders like Tesco Express, Sainsbury's Local, and numerous discount retailers. Morrisons has committed to providing job opportunities to former My Local employees.

During Greybull Capital's management, My Local encountered numerous intricate problems. The commercial landscape became tough due to elevated operational expenses, fierce price competition, and evolving consumer purchasing patterns. Even after attempting to rebrand its stores as ‘My Local’ and implement a community-centric approach, the chain failed to achieve substantial market presence or consistent profitability. KPMG's involvement as administrators was a direct consequence of prolonged and severe financial pressure, indicating that a sustainable future without extensive reorganization was unachievable.

KPMG's immediate priority involves overseeing the shutdown of the 93 unprofitable sites and diligently searching for purchasers for the remaining 32. Experts familiar with company administrations suggest that securing a sole buyer for this entire portfolio could prove difficult; consequently, these outlets might be sold off individually or in smaller groups to other retail chains or convenience businesses. Regrettably, a substantial number of the 1,658 jobs will be eliminated as a result of these closures. Nevertheless, Morrisons’ proactive promise to re-employ former My Local employees, when practical, provides some comfort to those impacted, emphasizing its lasting association with the brand it initially established before its sale.

The collapse of My Local highlights the inherent difficulties within the convenience retail segment, even for seemingly strong businesses. This represents a significant disappointment for Greybull Capital, adding another mixed result to their investment history. The destiny of the remaining 32 stores now depends entirely on KPMG's ability to quickly find buyers. If these efforts are unsuccessful, those locations will also assuredly close, leading to the complete disappearance of the My Local brand from local retail landscapes, just over a year since its highly publicized re-launch under Greybull's ownership.

Lord Advocate Frank Mulholland also told MSPs that a fatal accident inquiry would be held into the death.
Mr Bayoh, 31, died in police custody after being detained following an incident in Kirkcaldy on 3 May.
His family welcomed the comments and said they hoped the Lord Advocate would establish "the truth of what happened".
Mr Mullholland told MSPs that further work was needed by the Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), particularly into the cause of death, before the investigation was completed.
"Having met the family on two occasions, I know the effect that this tragedy has had on them and they have borne their loss with great dignity," he said.
"They are right to demand answers and a thorough, impartial and objective investigation is what they deserve."
Mr Mulholland said he was confident this could be done "expeditiously without compromising thoroughness".
He added that regardless of the decision on criminal proceedings, a fatal accident inquiry would be held because Mr Bayoh had died in custody.
"A fatal accident inquiry will allow all the evidence to be presented in a court, open to the public and the media, to be rigorously tested by all parties represented at the FAI, including the family, and allow the sheriff to make findings in fact and recommendations in relation to Sheku's death in a judgement that will be available to all," he said.
Aamer Anwar, the solicitor for Mr Bayoh's family, said: "The family have always known that there would be an FAI but they do not believe at this stage that this is a solution to the death in custody of Sheku Bayoh.
"An FAI is, in essence, the bare minimum of what can happen, but at this stage it would be premature to predict the outcome of the investigations if they are truly robust and impartial.
"It has been 19 weeks since Sheku's death and the family hope the Lord Advocate can provide them with the truth of what happened, because without that they know there can be no justice."

A forthcoming cabinet meeting will investigate findings that seventeen interim contractors received daily payments exceeding £500, with two earning over £800 each day. Plymouth City Council's Labour administration faced immediate, strong condemnation from the opposition Conservatives. Councillor Ian Bowyer, leader of the Conservative group, denounced this spending on temporary personnel as a "scandalous waste of public funds."

Bowyer expressed profound disappointment, deeming it indefensible that the Labour council permits millions to be spent on external advisors commanding exorbitant daily fees, especially when vital frontline services are facing cuts and residents are experiencing financial hardship. He argued that this signifies not just poor financial oversight but a serious breach of public trust. The Conservatives, he noted, have consistently advocated for greater transparency and accountability regarding the council's use of agency staff.

These unusually high remuneration packages, he continued, expose a significant weakness in the council's employment strategy, suggesting an excessive reliance on expensive short-term fixes instead of cultivating lasting internal expertise. Bowyer emphasized that the public is entitled to an explanation for the necessity and value provided by these highly compensated temporary workers, particularly given that permanent council employees face wage freezes. He concluded that this unmistakably demonstrates the Labour group's incompetence in managing city finances responsibly, prioritizing costly, improvised solutions over strategic, sustainable planning for Plymouth's future.

During the extensive Thameslink Programme, engineers unearthed the long-lost ticket hall and platforms of Southwark Park station. This station operated for a remarkably short period, serving commuters for just thirteen years from 1902 until its permanent shutdown in 1915. The unexpected finding of the disused Southwark Park station highlights the deep historical layers often uncovered by engineers working on significant modern infrastructure developments.

The ambitious £6.5 billion Thameslink Programme involves a major upgrade of railway lines, stretching from New Cross Gate, through central London stations such as London Bridge and Blackfriars, up to St Pancras International. This massive project aims to fundamentally reshape north-south rail links across the capital and the wider South East. This substantial investment is intended to significantly boost railway capacity and enhance network integration, allowing for more frequent, longer, and higher-volume train services to run smoothly through the heart of the city.

Key elements of the Thameslink Programme include extensive renovations of vital stations like London Bridge, alongside the construction of new railway infrastructure, all strategically designed to support these improved services. Ultimately, the programme will establish connections to an even broader range of destinations, connecting locations as far south as Brighton with northern centres such as Peterborough and Cambridge, guaranteeing dependable and continuous journeys across the capital. This crucial transport scheme directly tackles increasing passenger demand, promising less congestion and a considerably more efficient and resilient rail system for millions of daily commuters and travellers, thus strategically future-proofing the railway network.

Hundreds of passengers aboard a Thomson Holidays flight arrived safely at the airport, their Boeing 737 making a secure landing at approximately 3:30 PM BST. The aircraft then promptly proceeded to its designated gate, where ground crew were ready to assist with disembarkation. This efficient arrival highlighted effective airport management, ensuring all travelers, after a comfortable journey, were eager to begin their holiday plans.

Following Welsh international Taylor's injury during Wednesday's training, Swansea manager Paul Clement is working to finalize a transfer for Norwich City's Swedish international, Martin Olsson. Clement has stressed his goal to strengthen the squad, particularly in defence, viewing Olsson as a crucial acquisition. The left-back is reportedly in South Wales for a medical examination and discussions, with a deal potentially concluded before the weekend. Eager to establish his authority since taking charge, Clement deems Olsson's signing essential for his plan to avert Premier League relegation.

The study tracked more than 200,000 Australian smokers and non-smokers above the age of 45 over six years.
Mortality risk went up with cigarette use, BMC Medicine reports.
Smoking 10 cigarettes a day doubled the risk, while 20-a-day smokers were four to five times more likely to die.
Although someone who smokes could lead a long life, their habit makes this less likely.
Smoking increases the risk of a multitude of health problems, including heart disease and cancer.
Cancer Research UK currently advises that half of all long-term smokers eventually die from cancer or other smoking-related illnesses.
But recent evidence suggests the figure may be higher.
Newer studies in UK women, British doctors and American Cancer Society volunteers have put the figure at up to 67%, says Prof Emily Banks, lead author of the Australian study.
"We knew smoking was bad, but we now have direct independent evidence that confirms the disturbing findings that have been emerging internationally.
"Even with the very low rates of smoking that we have in Australia, we found that smokers have around threefold the risk of premature death of those who have never smoked. We also found smokers will die an estimated 10 years earlier than non-smokers," she said.
George Butterworth, tobacco policy manager at Cancer Research UK, said: "It's a real concern that the devastation caused by smoking may be even greater than we previously thought.
"Earlier research has shown, as a conservative estimate, one in two long-term smokers die from smoking-related diseases in the UK, but these new Australian figures show a higher risk.
"Smoking habits differ between Australia and the UK [in terms of] how much people smoke and the age they start, so we can't conclude that the two-in-three figure necessarily applies to the UK."
In Australia, about 13% of adults smoke. In the UK, the figure is about 20%.
Stopping smoking can bring a person's health risks back down.
Ten years after quitting, risk of lung cancer falls to half that of a smoker and risk of heart attack falls to the same as someone who has never smoked, according to NHS Smokefree.

An extensive archive, encompassing a substantial collection of photographs, an array of military medals, and various service badges, is scheduled for auction in July. Auctioneer Charles Hanson enthusiastically described this remarkable discovery as a "time capsule," which promises to offer fresh perspectives and deeper insights into the conflict. The photographs were meticulously captured by Robert Oliver, an esteemed sergeant in the Royal Army Medical Corps, a man who not only served with distinction during the war but also personally endured its severe and harsh conditions. His carefully preserved collection, a true treasure trove, provides an unrivaled glimpse into the daily lives of soldiers, the challenging environments they confronted, and the grim realities of early 20th-century warfare.

Prominently featured among the significant artifacts is his highly regarded Queen's Medal for South Africa, complete with multiple clasps, serving as undeniable proof of his bravery and active involvement in numerous critical campaigns, including those fought within the Orange Free State. This remarkable assemblage not only meticulously chronicles Oliver's personal experiences but also furnishes vital historical context for the British Empire's military operations during a period of substantial global transformation. Charles Hanson further underscored the exceptional uniqueness of such a comprehensive and profoundly personal collection, presenting historians and collectors with a singular, unparalleled opportunity to gain direct access to history.

Oliver’s photographic work reveals both the unwavering steadfast endurance of the troops and surprising, often poignant, instances of fellowship and quiet contemplation, offering a sharp divergence from the frequently posed and formal images common to that era. These authentic pictures, presented alongside his military medals and other personal effects, clearly depict a man who witnessed historical events as they unfolded and possessed the profound foresight to diligently document them. The vast extent of this meticulously organized archive, detailing everything from frontline medical posts to wide-ranging troop movements across the veld, establishes it as a priceless primary source for comprehending the immense personal toll and complex strategic difficulties encountered by British forces. It truly embodies, as Hanson perceptively observed, a repository rich in untold stories and forgotten viewpoints that necessitate a fundamental reassessment of existing accounts of the conflict. The forthcoming auction is widely anticipated to attract considerable international attention, owing to the remarkable character and profound historical significance of Oliver’s comprehensive records concerning one of the British Empire's most demanding conflicts.

From September to November, three related incidents, attributed to a single individual, have occurred near the Hillhead Halls of Residence. The individual is described as a white male, roughly 5 feet 8 inches in height, with a slim build and short, dark hair, believed to be aged 17 to 20. He was reportedly seen wearing a dark hooded top and dark trousers on every occasion.

The initial incident occurred on the evening of Friday, September 15th, when a female student was approached and subsequently followed. A second event, on Tuesday, October 3rd, involved a similar approach that progressed to an attempted theft. The latest report, on Wednesday, November 8th, described an incident that resulted in an assault, though the victim sustained no serious injuries. These events, all happening in close proximity to the Hillhead Halls, have understandably caused significant concern among both students and university staff.

Detective Constable Kirsty Munro, who is heading the inquiry, stated that police are treating these matters with utmost seriousness and have increased patrols around the Hillhead Halls area as a result. She urged anyone with any information, no matter how minor it appears, to come forward, emphasizing that identifying this individual is crucial for preventing further incidents. Residents are advised to remain vigilant and promptly report any suspicious activity directly to an officer, by calling 101, or anonymously through Crimestoppers.

After its close flyby on Tuesday, the probe successfully reported its condition, confirming a smooth journey past the frigid cosmic object. This impressive maneuver was executed at an incredible velocity of 14 kilometers per second (31,000 mph). A vital data stream, containing essential updates, was received by a colossal antenna located in Madrid, Spain, a critical component of NASA's worldwide communication system. This crucial message traveled an astronomical 4.7 billion kilometers across the void of space, taking four hours and twenty-five minutes to arrive on Earth. Personnel at the mission operations center in Laurel, Maryland, had eagerly anticipated this crucial update. A palpable sense of relief and elation filled the room once the robust signal, brimming with invaluable findings, was finally verified. The control room erupted in cheers, hugs, and congratulatory gestures, celebrating the successful conclusion of years of tireless work, precise preparation, and numerous late nights. The successful transmission of this data not only validated the spacecraft's health following its demanding approach but also guaranteed the secure delivery of all collected intelligence.

Preliminary data packets swiftly confirmed that all instruments aboard, including its advanced high-resolution cameras, spectrometers, and magnetometers, were operating flawlessly. Researchers promptly commenced analyzing the unprocessed information, keen to acquire their initial understanding of the enigmatic frozen world. This successful transit signifies a monumental accomplishment in humanity's push to explore the outer reaches of our solar system, expanding the limits of scientific endeavor and providing a never-before-seen view of a cosmic body that was previously barely discernible. The forthcoming information is poised to significantly alter our knowledge of frigid geological phenomena, the possibility of hidden oceans, and environmental factors potentially conducive to extraterrestrial life.

The mission's researchers expect to spend many months, perhaps even years, meticulously examining the enormous volume of received data. Every piece of information has the potential to solve new cosmic riddles, from the precise makeup of the ice to indications of geysers or subsurface movements. The probe's astonishing voyage, spanning billions of kilometers from Earth, has now yielded its initial, significant reward, showcasing the exceptional cleverness of its engineers and the steadfast dedication of its science team. This vital 'dispatch home' stands not merely as a technological triumph but also as a powerful affirmation of humankind's lasting inquisitiveness and innate urge to venture into the universe. Upcoming visuals and spectroscopic measurements will furnish an abundance of specifics regarding the world's surface features, any detectable atmosphere, and its magnetic field dynamics, allowing for the creation of a complete understanding of this remote, mysterious object. Having successfully overcome the immediate hurdles of the flyby and data relay, the mission collective now commences the equally thrilling work of interpreting the spacecraft's findings and converting them into pioneering insights. This initial triumph lays the groundwork for in-depth investigation and possibly future expeditions to comparable destinations, all propelled by the profound knowledge gained from this remarkable close approach.

On Monday, Mrs May met the first and deputy first ministers on a one-day visit to Northern Ireland.
She stressed that no-one wanted a return to the "borders of the past".
Her meeting with Mr Kenny is understood to have focused on the impact of Brexit on British and Irish relations.
Earlier in July, shortly after her appointment as the new prime minister, Mrs May spoke to Mr Kenny by telephone and agreed to build on the "strong relationship"  between the UK and the Republic of Ireland..
Northern Ireland Secretary of State James Brokenshire described Mrs May's meeting with Arlene Foster and Martin McGuinness on Monday as "positive".
He also said there was agreement about protecting the current border arrangements between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland.
"I think that the prime minister had a really helpful exchange with the first minister and the deputy first minister and I think there is a strong will and strong commitment to not see the return to the borders of the past," he said.
"Indeed that's a theme that underlined discussions that I previously had with the taoiseach on Friday."
Mr Brokenshire added that there were "treaties and various other mechanisms" in place that underlined that there was a "different arrangement" between the United Kingdom and the Republic of Ireland.
Deputy First Minister Martin McGuinness said he hoped there would be an "arrangement which will see the people of the north of Ireland continuing to see their future in Europe as part of an imaginative solution."
The DUP MP Gavin Robinson said there were "two aspects" that had to be considered relating to the border.
"So far, discussions have focussed on the movement of people, there will also need to be a discussion about the movement of goods, customs and whether or not there is a form of a single market or not, whether there is a disparity in tariffs or not and if that is the case, then how you control that," he said.
"So whilst I see no difficulty in getting an arrangement that builds on the Common Travel Area and that allows you and I to move freely into the Republic of Ireland and similarly people from the Republic of Ireland can move freely into the United Kingdom, knowing that we have a uniform immigration policy, it may well be that further discussions will need to take place."

An employee at Southport's Freshway General store sustained a facial injury and was deeply shaken after an armed robbery occurred on Tuesday evening, around 9 PM BST. Merseyside Police are seeking witnesses to this incident, which Detective Inspector Steve Reardon described as a "shocking and violent attack" on a lone staff member. He confirmed that multiple investigative avenues are being explored and urged anyone nearby with suspicious observations or relevant dashcam footage to contact them without delay, emphasizing that even minor details could be vital. Local residents will also observe an increase in police patrols for reassurance.

A mother and her teenage daughter were reportedly dragged from their vehicle by multiple attackers on Friday, along the highway linking Noida (a Delhi suburb) and Kanpur. Three male relatives accompanying them were assaulted and held captive. This incident has ignited nationwide outrage, highlighting serious concerns about women's safety, particularly on Uttar Pradesh's national routes. The horrific offense, which took place near Bulandshahr, has reignited heated debates about the state's public order. The Hindustan Times reported that the victims were forcefully removed from their car, while the male relatives, including the family's eldest member, were tied up and beaten. Subsequently, the women were allegedly gang-raped by the perpetrators.

The sheer brutality of this assault on a crucial highway stretch, connecting the bustling Delhi suburb of Noida with Kanpur, has profoundly shocked the country. Politicians, women's rights advocates, and the general public have condemned these events, demanding prompt justice for the victims and severe penalties for those responsible. Protests have erupted in various cities, with demonstrators voicing their anger and fear, and insisting on accountability from the state government. Critics point to a clear security failure, stressing the vulnerability of individuals journeying on these often isolated routes. The Uttar Pradesh Police have initiated an extensive search operation, deploying numerous teams to apprehend the perpetrators, and senior officials have vowed an uncompromising pursuit of justice. This incident sharply underscores the ongoing difficulties in ensuring basic public safety, necessitating a re-evaluation of security protocols across the nation's transport network.

According to BBC Technology correspondent Chris Foxx on January 18, 2016, at 19:54 GMT, Virtual Private Networks notably enhance online privacy and security. He detailed their advantages for users, especially in January, given the rise in digital surveillance.

Annually on March 8th, a celebratory event features parades, speeches, and special assemblies. This date was specifically picked to showcase significant achievements, particularly in sports. This year, Oxfordshire's festivities will welcome Olympians Rebecca Adlington and Charlotte Dujardin, both OBE recipients. Sophie, a leading figure in community initiatives, is also anticipated. The occasion aims to foster local pride and acknowledge these individuals' inspiring influence on the national sporting landscape.

The International Bomber Command Centre, situated near Lincoln in Lincolnshire, stands as a profound tribute, marked by its distinctive 102-foot spire. This striking structure not only mirrors the expansive wingspan of a Lancaster bomber but also powerfully symbolizes the courage and ultimate sacrifice of those who served. The centre's core purpose is to honor the 55,573 Bomber Command aircrew members who perished during World War Two, many of them in hostile skies. Beyond mere commemoration, its vital mission is to educate future generations about the critical role Bomber Command played in the conflict and the immense human cost.

Recently, the memorial suffered an act of vandalism. Although the physical harm was minor, officials unequivocally condemned it as a significant act of disrespect. Investigators suspect the perpetrators used breeze blocks, found on site, in an attempt to breach the memorial's interior. This incident has caused deep distress among veterans and everyone dedicated to preserving Bomber Command's legacy, widely seen as a direct insult to both the fallen and their families.

Local police are actively investigating and urging any witnesses to come forward. The broader community, alongside numerous veterans' groups, has expressed widespread indignation, highlighting the sacred importance of such memorials as essential reminders of past sacrifices and the enduring pursuit of peace. Work is currently underway to repair the superficial damage and bolster security at this significant site, which regularly welcomes international visitors keen to learn about the bravery of World War Two aircrews.

But it is on the streets where a new generation of photographers is capturing the bustling megacity with their own perspectives. One of the most distinctive is 29-year-old Adeola Olagunju, who told the BBC how she captures Lagos.
Video Journalist: Roderick Macleod

In Castlemilk, Glasgow, a father and his son endured a brutal assault last Friday evening, around 8:05 PM. Police reports confirm the young boy was viciously attacked while walking along Ardencraig Quadrant, close to its intersection with Ardencraig Drive. His 52-year-old father, witnessing the violence unfold, was also set upon as he attempted to shield his son. Both individuals were subsequently hospitalized to treat injuries to their faces.

Police have initiated a thorough investigation into this alarming incident and are appealing for public assistance. Detective Inspector Peter McFarlane, who is leading the inquiry, described the assault as "senseless and brutal." He elaborated that this unprovoked act of aggression targeted a young boy and his father, whose sole intention was to defend him. This terrifying ordeal has left both victims deeply traumatized, and law enforcement is determined to identify and apprehend those responsible. While their facial wounds were not critical, they necessitated medical attention and caused considerable distress.

DI McFarlane urged anyone who was in the vicinity of Ardencraig Quadrant or Ardencraig Drive in Castlemilk, Glasgow, at the time of the attack to contact the police. He particularly sought information from individuals who may have noticed suspicious persons in the area or possess dashcam or private CCTV recordings that could aid the investigation. Emphasizing the potential importance of even seemingly minor details in reconstructing the events and pinpointing the assailants, he also addressed the concerns of local residents. He provided reassurance that comprehensive inquiries are being conducted and that officers will maintain a visible presence on patrol to alleviate community fears.

Anyone with pertinent information is asked to contact Police Scotland by dialling 101, quoting incident number [XXXX] from the day it occurred. Alternatively, anonymous submissions can be made to Crimestoppers at 0800 555 111. Authorities are dedicated to ensuring that those responsible for this reprehensible crime are brought to justice.

He was asked if a change in the law was being considered as part of a review of marriage laws.
"Not as far as I'm aware and I've certainly no intention of doing so," he told the BBC's Sunday Politics show.
The government was looking into humanist marriages in England and Wales, he said.
Humanism is a secular philosophy. Humanist weddings are not legally recognised in England, Wales and Northern Ireland - but they are legal in Scotland.
The Daily Mail reported on Tuesday that ministers had ordered a rethink of wedding laws, which could allow naturists to conduct weddings if the rules were changed.
It claimed a paper had been published by Mr Grayling which confirmed groups who have expressed an interest in changing wedding laws included British Naturism, the organisation that campaigns for a greater understanding and acceptance of outdoor nudism.
But Mr Grayling told the BBC: "It hasn't been ordered by me I can tell you that."
The justice secretary stressed there was a difference between someone "expressing an interest" and "something actually happening".
"No nude marriage right now as far as I'm concerned," he told the BBC.

Streets will be pedestrianised, new trees and plants added, and public art and cycle routes installed.
A University spokesperson said the work would make the campus more welcoming, safer and greener for everyone to use.
The scheme, funded by Sheffield City Region Investment Fund and the University, is due to be finished by the new academic year in September.
More on this story and other news from Sheffield & South Yorkshire
The public courtyards around the Arts Tower and Western Bank concourse will be improved, with a new public park created near Broad Lane.
New pedestrian and cycle crossings will be made, and existing ones improved.
Keith Lilley, director of estates and facilities management, said the development would "transform the campus environment and support the University's links with the city centre."
"We want to encourage the people of Sheffield to enjoy and use our campus whether it's to have lunch in one of our cafes, cycle through the campus area up to Weston Park, or just enjoy sitting and relaxing in one of the new greener, safer places that will be created through this development."
The university is providing ¬£5.1m for the work, with ¬£2.9m from Sheffield City Region Investment Fund.
Sheffield City Council's Leigh Bramall said: "Our universities are critical to the future of Sheffield and vital to the successful economic growth of the city."
He added the new campus would "emphasize the University's position as a key driver in the local economy."

Paul Newall, a 30-year-old Larkhall resident and respected community member, tragically lost his life on Saturday afternoon after a collision on the M74 northbound, near Hamilton's junction 7. His Kawasaki motorcycle was involved in a crash with a white Mazda 2 around 1:30 PM. Despite the rapid arrival of paramedics and police, Mr. Newall was pronounced dead at the scene. This tragic event led to a significant deployment of emergency services, and the motorway remained closed for several hours for a detailed accident inquiry. Police Scotland is now urging witnesses or anyone with dashcam footage to come forward as they investigate the circumstances of the fatal incident.

Zee Entertainment Enterprises has unveiled its plan to convert its extensive collection of Hindi Bollywood movies into Spanish. This new initiative, named Zee Mundo, represents the company's first step in introducing Indian films to the Hispanic demographic. Its primary goal is to connect with the rapidly expanding Spanish-speaking populations across the Americas, especially in vital regions such as Mexico and the United States. Although Bollywood enjoys global appeal, linguistic differences have often limited its wider penetration in areas where Hindi or English are not primary languages. By translating the Hindi dialogue into Spanish, Zee aims to overcome this obstacle, thereby making its vivid storytelling, elaborate musical sequences, and compelling narratives more accessible to a fresh audience segment. Zee Mundo will showcase a diverse array of genres, including action, romance, and drama, specifically adapted to regional cultural preferences, ensuring a rich and varied entertainment offering for its Hispanic viewers. This major expansion highlights Zee Entertainment Enterprises' commitment to expanding its international reach and securing a strong foothold in a previously unexplored market.

The captain pounced after Kieran Smith's shot was spilled by Peter Jehle in the visiting goal.
Vaduz had led 2-0 at half-time after goals in quick succession from Gonzalo Zarate and Maurice Brunner.
Stuart Jones should have claimed a late equaliser for Bala but headed just wide when Nathan Burke's free-kick found him unmarked at the back post.
The return leg at the Rheinpark Stadion in Vaduz is on Thursday, 6 July.
Ballymena United or Norwegian side Odd await the winners in the second qualifying round.
Bala manager Colin Caton told BBC Wales Sport:
"I don't think we started the game very well - we were very flat and wary of knowing the opposition.
"We still had good chances and a blatant penalty when Kieran [Smith] has gone through and has been pulled back.
"They had two chances in the first half and that's the difference at this level. It's a bit frustrating really... we have had the better chances.
"If we get the first goal out there, it's an away goal and they will be in a sticky situation.
"They were panicking towards the end here.
"It just frustrates me we have done ever so well but you have to take the chances at this level."

The death of 15-year-old Dione Melville in East Calder is currently under police investigation. Paramedics and other emergency personnel responded to a local home on Sunday morning, where Dione was unfortunately declared deceased soon after their arrival. A teenager has since been charged in connection with supplying drugs related to this event.

Police Scotland has confirmed the arrest and charging of a 17-year-old male for allegedly supplying controlled substances. He is scheduled to appear before Livingston Sheriff Court. The investigation into the circumstances surrounding Dione's passing continues, with a post-mortem examination planned to ascertain the exact cause of death.

Dione, a well-liked student at Livingston's St John's Academy, is being deeply grieved by her loved ones. Social media platforms are filled with emotional tributes expressing profound shock and sadness. Her family issued a statement describing her as "our beautiful girl, who was loved by everyone." Furthermore, Lisa Grubb, a close relative, posted a strong message online cautioning young individuals about the hazards of drug use.

Chief Inspector Alistair Leitch, the Local Area Commander, extended his sympathy to Dione's family and recognized the profound effect this incident has had on the East Calder community. He assured the public that a comprehensive investigation is in progress, with officers exploring various avenues.

Authorities are urging anyone with relevant information to contact Police Scotland at 101, referencing the specific incident number. As further details emerge, the community continues to feel a deep sense of impact from this event.

From 1995 to 2002, Princess Royal Barracks in Deepcut, Surrey, gained infamy due to a sequence of fatal incidents where four young service members died from gunshot wounds. Among the victims was Private Sean Benton, 20, whose body, bearing five gunshot wounds, was found in June 1995 while he was on perimeter guard duty. The other soldiers who perished were Private Cheryl James, Private Geoff Gray, Private James Collinson, and Private Kevin Williams. Authorities initially classified all four deaths as suicides, a conclusion fiercely and persistently challenged by their bereaved families over many years. These families relentlessly argued that the conditions surrounding their children's deaths were highly suspect and that the original inquiries were fundamentally inadequate and flawed. A pivotal moment occurred in 2016 when a fresh inquest into Private Cheryl James’s death, also at Deepcut in 1995, overturned the initial finding, ruling instead that she had been unlawfully killed. Buoyed by this crucial decision, Private Benton’s family, supported by the human rights organization Liberty, has since secured the Attorney General’s approval to formally petition for a new High Court inquest into his death.

The deaths at Deepcut rapidly evolved into a major national scandal, drawing critical attention to the British Army's welfare provisions, pervasive bullying claims, and its fundamental duty of care. The grieving families, frequently aided by human rights bodies such as Liberty, relentlessly sought to invalidate the initial inquest verdicts and secure new, unbiased investigations, firmly believing that vital evidence had been either overlooked or improperly managed during the initial proceedings. Private Cheryl James’s circumstances, specifically, became prominent again when her parents, Des and Doreen James, successfully secured a new inquest following years of arduous legal battles. This subsequent investigation brought to light powerful and disturbing evidence of an entrenched culture of intimidation, harassment, and even alleged sexual exploitation within the barracks, which her family vehemently contended was directly responsible for her untimely demise.

Parallel to these events, Private Sean Benton's family, whose son was also found dead at Deepcut Barracks in Surrey, has for an extended period campaigned for a fresh inquiry into his passing. His sister, Tracy Lewis, alongside other relatives, has persistently challenged the original suicide ruling, citing numerous discrepancies and omissions in the presented evidence, alongside a concerning absence of a thorough investigation at the time. The Attorney General’s recent decision to permit Private Benton’s family to apply to the High Court for a new inquest particularly underscores the profound and continuing anxieties concerning the honesty and exhaustive nature of the initial investigations into these deeply sorrowful deaths.

Driven by the exceptional tenacity and steadfast courage of the grieving families and their committed legal representatives, these pivotal and far-reaching cases have profoundly and permanently altered public understanding of military fatalities and the investigative protocols within the armed forces. They have forcefully emphasized the critical need for independent scrutiny and a clear, answerable judicial process when service members die outside of combat. The continuing review of these deeply unsettling events, notably through High Court processes and subsequent fresh inquests, marks a crucial and transformative phase in the collective quest for truth and accountability, extending a vital beacon of hope for a long-sought resolution to families who have endured decades of grief, ambiguity, and unanswered inquiries regarding their loved ones' deaths at Deepcut and comparable military establishments.

An inquiry has recommenced into the 2014 death of newborn Jonathan Percival, who died at a mere 36 hours old at the vicarage in Freckleton, Lancashire. This investigation, initially put on hold in October, was prompted by vastly differing accounts from his family. James Percival, 66, stated he performed mouth-to-mouth resuscitation on the infant, claiming the baby was born "blue" and not breathing, which necessitated immediate intervention, including chest compressions. Conversely, Jonathan's 30-year-old mother, Ruth Percival, challenged this assertion, stating she was present throughout the critical period and observed no such attempts by James to revive the child.

The proceedings were halted last October following fresh medical evidence that led the coroner to escalate the matter to legal authorities. By March, the Crown Prosecution Service concluded there were "insufficient grounds to pursue a prosecution against anyone in connection with Jonathan's death." This decision allowed Dr. James Adeley, the coroner, to resume the investigation, which had originally commenced the previous October, with the primary goal of determining the precise medical cause of the infant's demise.

While the new medical evidence that led to prosecutorial involvement remained undisclosed to the public, it was understood to have sparked questions regarding the circumstances of Jonathan's death and the care he received. Despite these concerns, the CPS determined that the criteria for prosecuting any individual were not satisfied. The Percival family, particularly Ruth, continues to express a strong desire for a complete understanding of what transpired. The reconvened hearing is expected to feature further expert medical testimony and will revisit the contradictory accounts provided by James and Ruth Percival. Ultimately, the coroner aims to provide a clear determination of the cause and events surrounding Jonathan's tragic death in Freckleton, highlighting the intricate nature and profound emotional impact this case has on all involved, especially the parents who seek answers.

The National Environment Research Council (NERC) faced criticism following a public competition to name its new polar research vessel, in which "Boaty McBoatface" decisively won the public vote. Professor Duncan Wingham of NERC conceded that the ensuing controversy entertained a wide audience. Conversely, certain Members of Parliament voiced apprehension regarding public amusement and potential ridicule, questioning the accountability of NERC's leadership. Despite the poll's unequivocal outcome, NERC ultimately chose not to name its new £200 million ship RRS Boaty McBoatface. Instead, it was christened RRS Sir David Attenborough, a choice intended to underscore its profound scientific mission and crucial role in understanding worldwide environmental transformations. This dismissal of the public's preferred name sparked extensive indignation and claims that NERC had disregarded public sentiment, leading to significant social media protests concerning perceived hypocrisy. Facing intense scrutiny, Professor Wingham defended NERC's decision, contending that a more dignified name was essential for a vessel undertaking vital polar and climate investigations. To mitigate public dissatisfaction, NERC offered a compromise: a remotely operated underwater vehicle (ROV) housed within the RRS Sir David Attenborough would be designated 'Boaty McBoatface'. This ingenious solution allowed the popular, unique name to integrate into the scientific mission, thus ensuring its lasting legacy.
